items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Buston and Ashford river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 20:00 today, 20/09/25. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow morning, 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message:
River levels are forecast to remain high during today, 20/09/2025 and may rise again later this evening due to prolonged rainfall.  

Flooding is possible from late afternoon on 20/09/2025 at locations near the Upper River Tees, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. 

The rain is expected to clear the area by 02:00AM, 21/09/2025. We are not expecting to issue any flood warnings. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  

This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 20/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wiske and other tributaries of the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message:
River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall today, Saturday 20/09/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect the River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck. Rainfall is expected throughout the day and into this evening. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 05:00AM on Sunday 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Coastal flooding is possible due to forecast high tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning.
Flooding is possible around the high tide between 2:00 AM and 6:00 AM on 21/09/2025.
Areas most at risk include beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads around Hendon, Seaburn and Seaham Harbour Docks.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve throughout the day so the risk of further flooding will reduce.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 21/09/2025.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
Flooding is possible between 05:30 - 08:15am on Sunday 21/09/2025. High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and tidal River Esk. We are closely monitoring the situation.

Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are entering a period of high astronomic tides, with unsettled weather conditions for the next few days, so this alert may be re-issued if required. 

This message will be updated by 5am on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Due to further rainfall overnight last night, rivers and lakes remain high, flooding of low-lying land will continue. Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Further rainfall is forecast today, 20/09/2025, however, weather conditions are expected to improve from Sunday. We are continuing to monitor rainfall, river, and lake levels and clearing debris from weed screens. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes

River levels are rising at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected after 18:00 today, 20/09/25.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.7m to 4.1m over night tonight, Cae Howel 2.0m to 2.5m Sunday morning.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Sunday 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall today, Saturday 20/09/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day but no further flooding is expected. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
Flooding is expected between 05:45 and 08:00AM on Sunday 21/09/2025 due to high tides, strong winds and large waves. Areas most at risk of flooding include properties around the leisure centre, and behind South Promenade as far as Hornsea Burton Road, including Grainger Road and Pasture Road. 
We continue to monitor the situation closely and are closing the North and South promenade floodgates. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the waves, and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 5AM on Sunday 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Rising river levels are rising due to heavy rainfall today, Saturday 20/09/2025. Flooding is possible overnight into tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Skell, River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 05:00AM on Sunday, 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront between 3am and 7am tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025. Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority, which will make access difficult.

The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level of 4.03 mAODN at 5am, on Sunday 21st September, which is 0.47m above tide tables, Wind Force 5, direction Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Sunday at 5.15pm is currently forecast to be below the Flood Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.

High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible around the high tide from 7:00 PM today 20/09/2025.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley of 6.16 mAODN at 07:00 PM on 20/09/2025, with westerley force 6 winds
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.
After this evenings high tide, the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are checking flood defences and closing flood gates.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 11:00 AM on 28109/2025.
All times are in British Summer Time

Areas most at risk include Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to Carlisle including Greystoke, Newton Reigny, Plumpton, Stockdalewath, Sebergham and Denton Holme in Carlisle. Further rainfall is forecast today, 20/09/2025, however, weather conditions are expected to improve from Sunday. We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

Due to rainfall overnight last night, rising river levels throughout today, 20/09/2025 may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible this evening, 20/09/2025. Areas most at risk include Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby. Further rainfall is forecast today, 20/09/2025, however, weather conditions are expected to improve from Sunday. We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

High lake levels are causing flooding, this is expected to continue throughout the weekend. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Lake levels are forecast to peak this evening and start slowly falling overnight into Sunday, 21/09/2025. We are continuing to monitor rainfall, river, and lake levels and closely monitoring the situation. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

Due to further rainfall this afternoon, rivers remain high, flooding of low-lying land will continue. Areas most at risk include Rivers Wampool and Ellen and other watercourses, from Dalston to Maryport including low lying areas around Wigton, Abbeytown, Silloth, Allonby, Aspatria and Dearham. Further rainfall is forecast today, 20/09/2025, however, weather conditions are expected to improve from Sunday. We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day but no further flooding is expected. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Colne and Fenay Beck Catchments
items.message:
River levels are rising due to heavy rainfall today. Flooding is possible overnight into tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025
We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Colne. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 11.00 on 21 September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mersey Uplands catchment including Hyde, Ashton-under-Lyne, Denton, Stalybridge and Glossop

floodArea.county: Barnsley, Cheshire East, Derbyshire, Oldham, Stockport, Tameside

items.message:
Forecast rainfall indicates river levels could reach flood thresholds overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mersey.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this afternoon and evening may lead to flooding as a result of recent heavy rain. Flooding is possible this evening and overnight, Saturday 20/09/2025 and through to tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nidd, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Land around the Upper River Nidd and its tributaries including How Stean Beck, Blayshaw Gill, Ramsgill Beck, Lul Beck, Foster Beck, Fosse Gill, Fell Beck and Darley Beck. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 5AM on Sunday, 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow morning, Sunday 21/09/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nidd, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Land around the Middle River Nidd and its tributaries including Thornton Beck, Newton Beck, Oak Beck, Cow Dyke Beck, Bilton Beck, Frogmire Dike and Syke Dike. 
Rainfall is expected throughout the day and into this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation and do not expect to issue any flood warnings at this time. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 5am on Sunday 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible around the high tide from 7:00 PM today 20/09/2025.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley of 5.93 mAODN at 07:00 PM on 20/09/2025, with westerly force 7 winds
Areas most at risk include coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
All times referenced are in British Summer Time

Heavy rainfall and rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this evening.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Tue Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Tue Brook at Clubmoor, areas around Lindsay Road, Abingdon Road, Daneville Road and Frampton Road.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
